name: leaper
description: `Tab` to jump out of autoclosing pairs like braces and quotes.

untrustedWorkspaces.description: Workspace specific decoration options are ignored in untrusted workspaces since malicious workspaces can specify complex decorations that might severely affect the performance of the editor.

leaper.decorateAll.markdownDescription:
If `true`, will decorate all detected pairs. 

If `false`, will only decorate the detected pairs nearest to each cursor.

leaper.detectedPairs.$comment: Max items is limited to 100 to prevent a malicious workspace from slowing down the extension by specifying a really big array.
leaper.detectedPairs.markdownDescription:
The autoclosing pairs to detect. 

Note that there is no support for pairs that are more than 1 character wide on either side, so `(())`, for instance, is disallowed.

leaper.decorationOptions.markdownDescription:
How the closing side of each pair is decorated. 

This configuration expects a [`DecorationRenderOptions`](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#DecorationRenderOptions) object, and all options (except for `rangeBehavior`) can be configured. 

However, options aside from the ones related to "outline", "border" or "font" have not been tested, and use of them may cause unwanted side-effects. It is possible for heavy and complicated decorations to slow down or even crash the editor. Unfortunately, because there are so many different options available, and newer ones are always being introduced into vscode's API, there is no way to test all the possible combinations of options. 

Any option that expects a non-`string` type can be specified with an object literal matching the structure of that type. For example, see the default value of this configuration, where for the `outlineColor` option, an object literal matching the structure of a [`ThemeColor`](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#ThemeColor) was specified. 

Decorations can be disabled by setting this configuration to `{}`.

leaper.decorateOnlyNearestPair.$comment: This configuration was replaced with `leaper.decorateAll` since that configuration's name is clearer as to what its purpose is.
leaper.decorateOnlyNearestPair.markdownDescription: If `false`, will decorate all pairs instead of just the nearest one.

leaper.additionalTriggerPairs.$comment: This configuration was replaced with `leaper.detectedPairs`, as that configuration's value has a simpler format. Furthermore, the new configuration allows users to disable detection of the default set of pairs, whereas the default set of pairs in this configuration is hardcoded and cannot be changed.
leaper.additionalTriggerPairs.markdownDescription: Set additional pairs that the extension will detect. Currently there is no support for pairs that are more than 1 character wide on each side.

leaper.customDecorationOptions.$comment: The default value of this config is null because the default value is hardcoded in the source code. This configuration was replaced with `leaper.decorationOptions` since that configuration's name is clearer as to what its purpose is.
leaper.customDecorationOptions.markdownDescription: Customize the decoration of the closing character of the pair.

scripts.build-release: npm run lint && npm run typecheck && esbuild ./src/extension.ts --bundle --outfile=out/extension.js --external:vscode --format=cjs --platform=node --minify
